  • Variables are used to store data values in JavaScript.
  • They can be declared with the keywords var, let, or const.
  • var has global scope, let has block scope, and const is used for values that should not be changed.

// Example let age = 27; // declares a variable age and assigns a value of 27 const name = "John"; // declares a constant name and assigns a value

Sure, here's a summary of Variables and Conditionals in JavaScript:

Variables

  • Variables are used to store data or values in JavaScript.
  • They are declared using the let, const, or var keywords, with let and const being preferred due to their block-scoping nature.
  • Variables can store different types of data, including numbers, strings, booleans, objects, and arrays.
  • The value of a variable can be updated by assigning a new value to it using the assignment operator =.

Example:

javascript
let num = 10; // declare a variable 'num' and assign a value of 10 to it
const name = 'John'; // declare a constant variable 'name' and assign a value of 'John' to it
var isTrue = true; // declare a variable 'isTrue' and assign a value of true to it

num = 20; // update the value of 'num' to 20

Exercises:

  1. Declare a variable age and assign a value of 25 to it. Then, update the value of age to 30 and log it to the console.
javascript
let age = 25; // declare a variable 'age' and assign a value of 25 to it
age = 30; // update the value of 'age' to 30
console.log(age); // log the updated value of 'age' to the console
  1. Declare a constant variable PI and assign a value of 3.14 to it. Then, try to update the value of PI to 3.1416 and observe the error.
javascript
const PI = 3.14; // declare a constant variable 'PI' and assign a value of 3.14 to it
PI = 3.1416; // try to update the value of 'PI' to 3.1416, which will result in a TypeError
// the error will say "Assignment to constant variable."

Conditionals

  • Conditionals are used to execute different code blocks based on whether a certain condition is true or false.
  • The most commonly used conditional statements are if, else if, and else.
  • Conditionals rely on boolean values, which can be obtained through comparison operators like ==, ===, !=, !==, <, >, <=, and >=.
  • Conditionals can also be combined using logical operators like && (and), || (or), and ! (not).

**Example:

Variables

Variables are containers that hold values that can be changed or accessed throughout a program.

javascript
// Declare a variable with the let keyword and assign it a value

// Declare a variable with the const keyword, which is a read-only variable that cannot be reassigned

Sure, here's a summary of Variables and Conditionals in JavaScript:

Variables

  • Variables are used to store data values in JavaScript.
  • They are declared using the var, let, or const keyword.
  • var and let can be re-assigned, while const cannot.
  • Variables can hold different data types such as strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, objects, etc.

Example:

javascript
// Declaring variables using var, let, and const
var x = 10; // var
let y = "Hello World"; // let
const z = true; // const

// Re-assigning variables
x = 5; // var
y = "Goodbye"; // let - can be re-assigned
z = false; // const - cannot be re-assigned

Exercise 1: Declare a variable myName and assign it the value of your name. Print it to the console.

javascript
let myName = "John";
console.log(myName);

Exercise 2: Declare a variable myAge and assign it the value of your age. Declare another variable nextYearAge and assign it the value of your age plus one. Print both variables to the console.

javascript
let myAge = 30;
let nextYearAge = myAge + 1;
console.log("My age:", myAge);
console.log("Next year's age:", nextYearAge);

Conditionals

  • Conditionals are used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.
  • They are created using the if, else if, and else statements.
  • Conditionals use comparison operators such as ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=, as well as logical operators such as &&, ||, and !.

Example:

javascript
// Using if statement
let age = 18;
if (age >= 18) {
  console.log("You are an adult.");
}

// Using if else statement
let time = 20;
if (time < 18) {
  console.log("Good day.");
} else {
  console.log("Good evening.");
}

// Using if else if statement
let grade = 70;
if (grade >= 90) {
  console.log("A");
} else if (grade >= 80) {
  console.log("B");
} else if (grade >= 70) {
  console.log("C");
} else {
  console.log("F");
}

Exercise 1: Declare a variable temperature and assign it the value of the current temperature. Write a conditional statement that logs "It's hot!" if the temperature is greater than or equal to 80, "It's warm." if the temperature is between 60 and 79, and "It's cold." if the temperature is less than 60.

javascript
let temperature = 75;

if (temperature >= 80) {
  console.log("It's hot!");
} else if (temperature >= 60) {
  console.log("It's warm.");
} else {
  console.log("It's cold.");
}

Exercise 2: Declare a variable isStudent and assign it a boolean value. If the value of isStudent is true, log "Welcome, student!" to the console. If the value is false, log "Welcome, guest!" to the console.

javascript
let isStudent = true;

if (isStudent) {
  console.log("Welcome, student!");
} else {
  console.log("Welcome, guest!");
}

Sure, here's a summary for Logical Operators:

Logical Operators

  • Logical operators are used to combine and manipulate boolean values.
  • There are three logical operators in JavaScript: && (and), || (or), and ! (not).

Example:

javascript
let x = 5;
let y = 10;

if (x > 0 && y > 0) { // checks if both x and y are greater than 0
  console.log("Both x and y are positive");
}

if (x > 0 || y < 0) { // checks if either x is greater than 0 or y is less than 0
  console.log("Either x is positive or y is negative");
}

if (!(x > 0)) { // checks if x is NOT greater than 0
  console.log("x is not positive");
}

In the example above, the && operator is used to check if both x and y are positive, the || operator is used to check if either x is positive or y is negative, and the ! operator is used to check if x is not positive.

Exercises:

Exercise 1:

Create a function called canDrive that takes in two parameters, age and hasLicense. The function should return true if the person is over 18 years old and has a license, or false otherwise.

javascript
function canDrive(age, hasLicense) {
  return age > 18 && hasLicense;
}

console.log(canDrive(20, true)); // true
console.log(canDrive(16, true)); // false
console.log(canDrive(20, false)); // false

In the example above, the canDrive function uses the && operator to check if both age is greater than 18 and the person has a license.

Exercise 2:

Create a function called isVowel that takes in a parameter letter. The function should return true if the letter is a vowel (a, e, i, o, u), or false otherwise.

javascript
function isVowel(letter) {
  return letter === 'a' || letter === 'e' || letter === 'i' || letter === 'o' || letter === 'u';
}

console.log(isVowel('a')); // true
console.log(isVowel('b')); // false
console.log(isVowel('e')); // true

In the example above, the isVowel function uses the || operator to check if the letter is equal to any of the vowels.

Sure, here's the summary for Functions:

  1. Short Description: Functions are blocks of code that can be executed whenever they are called. They allow you to reuse code and make it more modular. Functions can take arguments, perform actions, and return a value.

  2. Example:

javascript
// A function that takes two arguments and returns their sum
function add(num1, num2) {
  return num1 + num2;
}

// Calling the function with arguments 5 and 7
let result = add(5, 7);

// Printing the result to the console
console.log(result);

In this example, we define a function called add that takes two arguments num1 and num2, performs an addition operation on them using the + operator, and returns the result. We then call the function with arguments 5 and 7 and store the result in a variable called result. Finally, we print the result to the console using console.log().

  1. Exercises and Solutions:

Exercise 1: Write a function that takes a string as an argument and returns the length of the string.

javascript
function getLength(str) {
  return str.length;
}

let myString = "Hello, world!";
let length = getLength(myString);

console.log(length); // Outputs 13

Exercise 2: Write a function that takes an array of numbers as an argument and returns the sum of all the numbers.

bash
function sumArray(arr) {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    sum += arr[i];
  }
  return sum;
}

let myArray = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let total = sumArray(myArray);

console.log(total); // Outputs 15

In the first exercise, we define a function called getLength that takes a string argument str and returns the length of the string using the length property of strings. We then call the function with a string argument "Hello, world!" and store the result in a variable called length. Finally, we print the result to the console using console.log().

In the second exercise, we define a function called sumArray that takes an array argument arr and uses a for loop to iterate through the array and add up all the numbers using a variable called sum. We then call the function with an array of numbers [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] and store the result in a variable called total. Finally, we print the result to the console using console.log().

Sure, here's the summary for Arrays:

  1. Title: Arrays
    • An ordered collection of data of any type
    • Can be accessed using index numbers
    • Can be iterated using loops
  2. Example:
    javascript
    // create an array
let fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'orange'];

// access an element by index
console.log(fruits[1]); // 'banana'

// add an element at the end
fruits.push('pear');

// remove an element from the end
fruits.pop();

// iterate through the array using a for loop
for (let i = 0; i < fruits.length; i++) {
  console.log(fruits[i]);
}
    • The first line creates an array with three elements.
    • The second line accesses the element at index 1 ('banana') and logs it to the console.
    • The push() method adds a new element to the end of the array ('pear').
    • The pop() method removes the last element from the array ('pear').
    • The for loop iterates through the array and logs each element to the console.
  3. Exercises: a) Create an array of numbers and use a loop to calculate their sum.
    javascript
    let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let sum = 0;
for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
  sum += numbers[i];
}
console.log(sum); // 15
    b) Create an array of strings and use a loop to concatenate them into a single string.
    javascript
    let strings = ['hello', 'world', 'this', 'is', 'JavaScript'];
let concatenatedString = '';
for (let i = 0; i < strings.length; i++) {
  concatenatedString += strings[i] + ' ';
}
console.log(concatenatedString); // 'hello world this is JavaScript '

Sure, here is a summary of Objects in JavaScript:

  1. Title: Objects

    • Objects are a data type in JavaScript that allow you to store multiple pieces of data in a single variable.
    • Objects are created using curly braces {} and can contain properties and methods.
    • Properties are key-value pairs that store data, while methods are functions that can be called on an object.

  2. Example:

    javascript
    // Creating an object with properties and methods
let person = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  address: {
    street: "123 Main St",
    city: "New York",
    state: "NY"
  },
  sayHello: function() {
    console.log(`Hello, my name is ${this.name} and I am ${this.age} years old.`);
  }
};

// Accessing object properties and calling methods
console.log(person.name); // "John"
console.log(person.address.city); // "New York"
person.sayHello(); // "Hello, my name is John and I am 30 years old."

    In this example, we create an object called person with properties such as name, age, and address, which itself is another object with properties of its own. We also add a method called sayHello which prints a message with the object's name and age properties. We then demonstrate accessing object properties and calling the sayHello method.

  3. Exercises:

    a) Write a function that takes an object as an argument and returns the number of properties it has.

    javascript
    function countProperties(obj) {
  let count = 0;
  for (let prop in obj) {
    if (obj.hasOwnProperty(prop)) {
      count++;
    }
  }
  return count;
}

let person = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  address: {
    street: "123 Main St",
    city: "New York",
    state: "NY"
  }
};

console.log(countProperties(person)); // 3

    In this exercise, we create a function called countProperties which takes an object as an argument and uses a for...in loop to iterate over its properties. We use the hasOwnProperty method to check if the property belongs to the object itself (rather than its prototype chain) and increment a counter variable for each property. We then return the final count.

    b) Write a function that takes an object and a key as arguments and returns the value of the specified property, or undefined if the property doesn't exist.

    javascript
    function getProperty(obj, key) {
  return obj.hasOwnProperty(key) ? obj[key] : undefined;
}

let person = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  address: {
    street: "123 Main St",
    city: "New York",
    state: "NY"
  }
};

console.log(getProperty(person, "name")); // "John"
console.log(getProperty(person, "email")); // undefined

    In this exercise, we create a function called getProperty which takes an object and a key as arguments. We use the hasOwnProperty method to check if the object has the specified key, and return the corresponding value if it does, or undefined otherwise. We then demonstrate calling the function with our person object and two different keys to see the output.

Next: Loops
1 / 1

Sure, here's a summary of Loops in JavaScript:

  1. Short Description: Loops allow you to execute a block of code repeatedly. There are three types of loops in JavaScript: for loop, while loop, and do-while loop.

  2. An Example:

javascript
// Example of a for loop
for(let i=0; i<5; i++){
  console.log(i);
}
// Output: 0 1 2 3 4

// Example of a while loop
let i = 0;
while(i < 5){
  console.log(i);
  i++;
}
// Output: 0 1 2 3 4

// Example of a do-while loop
let i = 0;
do{
  console.log(i);
  i++;
}while(i < 5);
// Output: 0 1 2 3 4

In the above code, we have shown the examples of all three types of loops. The for loop executes the block of code for a fixed number of times, whereas the while loop and do-while loop executes the block of code until a certain condition is met. In the for loop, we declare a variable i and increment it with each iteration. In the while loop and do-while loop, we declare a variable i and increment it within the loop's body.

  1. Exercises and Solutions: Exercise 1: Write a program that prints the numbers from 1 to 10 using a for loop.
css
for(let i=1; i<=10; i++){
  console.log(i);
}

Exercise 2: Write a program that prints the even numbers between 0 and 20 using a while loop.

css
let i = 0;
while(i <= 20){
  if(i % 2 === 0){
    console.log(i);
  }
  i++;
}

In the above exercises, we have shown how to print numbers from 1 to 10 using a for loop and how to print even numbers between 0 and 20 using a while loop. In the first exercise, we declare a variable i and loop through until i is less than or equal to 10, incrementing it by 1 each time. In the second exercise, we declare a variable i and loop through until i is less than or equal to 20, checking whether i is even or not, and incrementing it by 1 each time.

Sure! Here's a summary for DOM selectors:

  1. Title: DOM Selectors

    • In JavaScript, the Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for web documents. It represents the page so that programs can change the document structure, style, and content.
    • DOM selectors are used to select elements in an HTML document so that we can interact with them using JavaScript.
    • There are several ways to select DOM elements, including by tag name, class name, ID, attribute, and CSS selector.

  2. Example:

    javascript
    // Selecting an element by tag name
const heading = document.getElementsByTagName("h1")[0]; // get the first h1 element

// Selecting an element by class name
const paragraphs = document.getElementsByClassName("paragraph");

// Selecting an element by ID
const element = document.getElementById("myElement");

// Selecting elements by CSS selector
const elements = document.querySelectorAll(".myClass > li");
    • The document.getElementsByTagName method returns a collection of all elements with the specified tag name.
    • The document.getElementsByClassName method returns a collection of all elements with the specified class name.
    • The document.getElementById method returns the element with the specified ID.
    • The document.querySelectorAll method returns a collection of all elements that match the specified CSS selector.

  3. Exercises:

    a) Select all the elements with the class "box" and change their background color to red.

    javascript
    const boxes = document.getElementsByClassName("box");

for (let i = 0; i < boxes.length; i++) {
  boxes[i].style.backgroundColor = "red";
}

    b) Select the element with the ID "button" and add a click event listener to it that displays an alert.

    javascript
    const button = document.getElementById("button");

button.addEventListener("click", function() {
  alert("Button clicked!");
});

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

Next: DOM Events (listen, events, react)
1 / 1

Sure! Here's a summary on DOM events in JavaScript:

  1. Description:

    • DOM (Document Object Model) events are actions or occurrences that happen in the browser, such as a user clicking on a button or the browser finishing loading a web page.
    • JavaScript can listen for these events and react accordingly by executing a set of instructions or invoking a function.
    • There are different types of events that can be listened to, such as mouse events, keyboard events, form events, and more.

  2. Example:

    javascript
    const button = document.querySelector('#myButton');

function handleClick() {
  console.log('Button clicked!');
}

button.addEventListener('click', handleClick);

    In this example, we select a button element from the DOM using document.querySelector(). We define a function handleClick() that logs a message to the console when the button is clicked. We then add an event listener to the button using button.addEventListener(), specifying the type of event to listen for (click) and the function to execute (handleClick).

  3. Exercises: a. Add an event listener to a text input field that listens for the keypress event and logs the value of the input field to the console whenever a key is pressed.

    javascript
    const input = document.querySelector('#myInput');

function handleKeypress(event) {
  console.log(event.target.value);
}

input.addEventListener('keypress', handleKeypress);

    In this example, we select a text input field from the DOM using document.querySelector(). We define a function handleKeypress() that logs the value of the input field to the console whenever a key is pressed. We add an event listener to the input field using input.addEventListener(), specifying the type of event to listen for (keypress) and the function to execute (handleKeypress).

Next: Scope (variable access)
1 / 1

Sure, here's a summary of scope in JavaScript:

  1. Title: Scope in JavaScript

  2. Example:

javascript
// Global scope
let message = "Hello, world!";

function showMessage() {
  // Local scope
  let message = "Hello, there!";
  console.log(message);
}

showMessage(); // Outputs "Hello, there!"
console.log(message); // Outputs "Hello, world!"

In this example, we have a global variable called message that has a value of "Hello, world!". We then define a function called showMessage which also has a variable called message with a value of "Hello, there!". When we call the showMessage function, it outputs the value of the local message variable. However, when we try to output the message variable outside of the function, it outputs the value of the global message variable.

  1. Exercises:

  let result = number * 2;
  return result;
}

console.log(counter); // Outputs 3

In this example, we have a global variable called counter that is accessed and modified by the incrementCounter function. Each time the function is called, the value of counter is increased by 1. By calling the function three times and outputting the value of counter each time, we can see that the value of counter has indeed been incremented.

Sure, here's a summary of the switch statement in JavaScript:

  1. Description: The switch statement is a control flow statement that evaluates an expression against multiple cases and executes code blocks for matching cases. It is often used as an alternative to a series of if-else statements.

  2. Example:

arduino
const day = "Wednesday";
switch (day) {
  case "Monday":
    console.log("Today is Monday");
    break;
  case "Tuesday":
    console.log("Today is Tuesday");
    break;
  case "Wednesday":
    console.log("Today is Wednesday");
    break;
  default:
    console.log("Not a valid day");
    break;
}

// In this example, the switch statement evaluates the day variable against three cases (Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday) and executes the corresponding console.log statement for the matching case. If there is no matching case, the default case is executed.

1 / 1

Sure, here's a summary for let and const:

  1. let and const
  • let and const are block-scoped variables in JavaScript.
  • let variables can be reassigned while const variables cannot be reassigned.
  • Use let when you need to reassign a variable and const when you want to create a read-only variable.
  1. Examples
javascript
let a = 1; // declare a variable with let and assign a value of 1
const b = 2; // declare a variable with const and assign a value of 2
{
  let a = 3; // declare another variable with let and assign a value of 3
  const b = 4; // declare another variable with const and assign a value of 4
  console.log(a); // prints 3
  console.log(b); // prints 4
}
console.log(a); // prints 1
console.log(b); // prints 2
  • In the above example, we have two blocks. Inside the first block, we declare new variables a and b with let and const respectively and assign them new values. We log the values of these variables inside the block and get 3 and 4. Outside the block, we log the values of a and b again and get 1 and 2 respectively.
  1. Exercises
  • Exercise 1: Write a function that takes an array of numbers and returns the sum of all the numbers in the array. Use let to declare a variable inside the function to store the sum.
javascript
function sumArray(numbers) {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
    sum += numbers[i];
  }
  return sum;
}
console.log(sumArray([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])); // prints 15
  • Exercise 2: Write a function that takes an object with two properties, width and height, and returns the area of a rectangle with those dimensions. Use const to declare a variable inside the function to store the area.
javascript

  const area = rectangle.width * rectangle.height;
  return area;
}
console.log(getRectangleArea({ width: 10, height: 5 })); // prints 50

Next: Destructuring

Sure, here's a summary of Destructuring in JavaScript:

  1. Description: Destructuring allows you to extract elements from an array or properties from an object and assign them to variables in a concise and readable manner. It simplifies code and can make it easier to work with data.

  2. Example:

javascript
// Destructuring an array
const myArray = [1, 2, 3, 4];
const [first, second, ...rest] = myArray;
// first is 1, second is 2, rest is [3, 4]

// Destructuring an object
const myObj = { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 };
const { a, b } = myObj;
// a is 1, b is 2

In the first example, we are destructuring an array and assigning the first element to the variable first, the second element to the variable second, and the rest of the elements to the array rest.

In the second example, we are destructuring an object and assigning the value of the property a to the variable a and the value of the property b to the variable b.

javascript

// your code here

javascript

const [, second, , fourth] = myArray;
console.log(second, fourth); // output: 20 40

b)

javascript

const { name, age } = myObj;
console.log(name, age); // output: John 30

javascript

In the above example, we declare two variables, name and age, and then use them inside a template string by enclosing them in ${}. When we log the greeting variable to the console, the output includes the values of the name and age variables within the string.

In this example, we use the toLocaleString() method to format the month as a long string, use the getDate() method to get the day of the month, and use the getFullYear() method to get the year. We then combine these values into a template string.

Arrow Functions
2 / 2

Sure, here's a summary for Arrow Functions:

  1. Short Description: Arrow functions are a shorthand way of writing functions in JavaScript. They are also known as "fat arrow" functions. Arrow functions have a more concise syntax compared to traditional function expressions and they have a few different behaviors regarding the this keyword.

  2. Example:

javascript
// Traditional Function
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

// Arrow Function
const add = (a, b) => a + b;

// Traditional Function
const multiply = function(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}

// Arrow Function
const multiply = (a, b) => {
  return a * b;
}

// Arrow Function with Implicit Return
const square = num => num * num;
  1. Exercises: a) Write an arrow function called double that takes a number as an argument and returns the number doubled.
arduino
const double = num => num * 2;

b) Write an arrow function called calculateArea that takes two numbers as arguments: width and height. The function should return the area of a rectangle with the given width and height.

arduino
const calculateArea = (width, height) => width * height;

Note: Arrow functions are a powerful tool in JavaScript and they have some important differences compared to traditional functions, especially when it comes to the behavior of the this keyword. Make sure to fully understand their capabilities and limitations before using them extensively in your code.

arrow functions
2 / 2

Sure! Here's a summary on arrow functions:

  1. Short Description: Arrow functions are a concise way to write functions in JavaScript, using a simpler syntax than traditional function expressions.

  2. Example:

vbnet
// Traditional function expression
function double(x) {
  return x * 2;
}

// Arrow function expression
const double = x => x * 2;

In the example above, we have a traditional function expression that takes a parameter x and returns its value multiplied by 2. The same functionality is achieved with an arrow function expression that uses a more concise syntax, where the parameter is enclosed in parentheses followed by the arrow =>, and the function body is expressed after the arrow.

Arrow functions also have implicit returns, meaning that if the function consists of a single expression, the return statement is implied and can be omitted.

javascript
// Traditional function expression
function isEven(num) {
  if (num % 2 === 0) {
    return true;
  } else {
    return false;
  }
}

// Arrow function expression with implicit return
const isEven = num => num % 2 === 0;

In this example, the traditional function expression checks if a number is even and returns a boolean value. The arrow function expression achieves the same result with a shorter syntax, and uses an implicit return since the function body consists of a single expression.

  1. Exercises: a) Write a traditional function expression that takes two parameters and returns their sum.
css
function sum(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

b) Rewrite the function from the previous exercise as an arrow function expression.

css
const sum = (a, b) => a + b;

Sure! Here's a summary of Arrow Functions in JavaScript:

  1. Short Description: Arrow functions are a shorthand syntax for writing anonymous functions in JavaScript. They provide a more concise syntax and automatically bind this to the surrounding context.

  2. An Example:

javascript
// A regular anonymous function
const multiply = function(x, y) {
  return x * y;
};

// The same function using arrow syntax
const multiplyArrow = (x, y) => x * y;

// Using arrow functions with array methods
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
const squared = numbers.map(x => x ** 2);
const sum = numbers.reduce((acc, curr) => acc + curr, 0);
  • The first example shows the syntax for defining an arrow function.
  • The second example shows how arrow functions can be used with array methods like map and reduce.

  1. Short Description: Arrow functions are a concise way to write functions in JavaScript. They have a simplified syntax and automatically bind to the context in which they are defined.

Closures
1 / 1
  1. Short Description:
  • A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer lexical scope, even after the outer function has returned.
  1. Example:
javascript
function outer() {
  const name = "John";
  
  function inner() {
    console.log(name);
  }
  
  return inner;
}

const innerFunc = outer();
innerFunc(); // Output: "John"

// Explanation: In this example, the inner function inner() is returned from the outer function outer(). Even though name is declared in outer(), inner() still has access to it through closure.

  1. Exercises and Solutions:

Exercise 1:

javascript
function add(num) {
  return function innerAdd(otherNum) {
    return num + otherNum;
  };
}

const addFive = add(5);
console.log(addFive(2)); // Output: 7
console.log(addFive(10)); // Output: 15

// Explanation: In this example, add() returns an inner function innerAdd(), which adds its argument to the num argument passed to add(). addFive is assigned to the result of add(5), and can now be called with an argument to add to 5.

Exercise 2:

javascript

  let count = 0;
  
  return {
    increment: function() {
      count++;
      console.log(count);
    },
    decrement: function() {
      count--;
      console.log(count);
    }
  };
}

const counter = makeCounter();
counter.increment(); // Output: 1
counter.increment(); // Output: 2
counter.decrement(); // Output: 1

// Explanation: In this example, makeCounter() returns an object with two methods, increment() and decrement(), that modify and log a count variable declared within the outer function. The counter variable is assigned to the returned object, and can now be used to call these methods.

Currying
1 / 1

Currying is a technique in functional programming that involves transforming a function that takes multiple arguments into a sequence of functions that each take a single argument. The resulting functions can then be called in a sequence to execute the original function with all of its arguments.

Example:

javascript
function add(a, b, c) {
  return a + b + c;
}

function curry(fn) {
  return function curried(...args) {
    if (args.length >= fn.length) {
      return fn.apply(this, args);
    } else {
      return function (...moreArgs) {
        return curried.apply(this, args.concat(moreArgs));
      };
    }
  };
}

const curriedAdd = curry(add);

console.log(curriedAdd(1)(2)(3)); // 6
console.log(curriedAdd(1, 2)(3)); // 6
console.log(curriedAdd(1)(2, 3)); // 6

In this example, the curry function is used to transform the add function into a curried version. The resulting curriedAdd function can be called with one argument at a time, and each call returns a new function that takes the next argument. When all arguments have been supplied, the final function returns the result of calling the original add function with all the arguments.

Exercise 1:

Implement a curry function that works with methods that have a variable number of arguments. Hint: use the arguments object.

javascript
function curry(fn) {
  return function curried(...args) {
    if (args.length >= fn.length) {
      return fn.apply(this, args);
    } else {
      return function (...moreArgs) {
        return curried.apply(this, args.concat(moreArgs));
      };
    }
  };
}

function logArgs() {
  console.log(arguments);
}

const curriedLogArgs = curry(logArgs);

curriedLogArgs(1, 2)(3, 4)(5); // logs: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Exercise 2:

Create a curried function that multiplies three numbers.

javascript
function multiply(a) {
  return function (b) {
    return function (c) {
      return a * b * c;
    };
  };
}

console.log(multiply(2)(3)(4)); // 24

Compose
2 / 2

Function composition is a technique in functional programming where multiple functions are combined to form a new function. This allows for a more declarative and composable way of creating complex logic.

Example:

javascript
const compose = (f, g) => x => f(g(x));
const addOne = x => x + 1;
const multiplyByTwo = x => x * 2;

const addOneAndMultiplyByTwo = compose(multiplyByTwo, addOne);

console.log(addOneAndMultiplyByTwo(5)); // Output: 12

In the example above, compose is a function that takes in two functions f and g and returns a new function that applies g to its input and then applies f to the result. addOne and multiplyByTwo are two simple functions that will be composed. The resulting function addOneAndMultiplyByTwo takes an input, adds 1 to it and then multiplies the result by 2.

Exercises:

  1. Write a function capitalize that takes in a string and returns a new string with the first letter capitalized.
javascript
const capitalize = str => str.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + str.slice(1);

console.log(capitalize("hello world")); // Output: "Hello world"
  1. Write a function reverse that takes in an array and returns a new array with the elements in reverse order.
javascript
const reverse = arr => arr.reverse();

console.log(reverse([1, 2, 3])); // Output: [3, 2, 1]

Functional Purity
3 / 3

Functional purity is a concept in functional programming that refers to functions that always produce the same output given the same input and do not have any side effects, such as modifying a variable outside the function's scope.

Example:

javascript
// impure function
let counter = 0;

function increment() {
  counter++;
  return counter;
}

console.log(increment()); // output: 1
console.log(increment()); // output: 2

// pure function
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

console.log(add(2, 3)); // output: 5
console.log(add(2, 3)); // output: 5

Exercises:

  1. Write a pure function that takes an array of numbers and returns a new array with each number squared.
javascript
const squareArray = arr => arr.map(num => num ** 2);

console.log(squareArray([1, 2, 3])); // output: [1, 4, 9]
  1. Write an impure function that takes a number and adds it to a global variable.
javascript
let sum = 0;

function addToSum(num) {
  sum += num;
}

addToSum(5);
console.log(sum); // output: 5

addToSum(10);
console.log(sum); // output: 15

  1. Short Description: Advanced Objects in JavaScript involves working with objects in more complex ways, such as creating classes and prototypes, working with inheritance and polymorphism, and using advanced object methods.

  2. Example: Here's an example of how to create a class in JavaScript using the class syntax and a constructor function:

javascript
class Animal {
  constructor(name, type, age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.type = type;
    this.age = age;
  }

  eat(food) {
    console.log(`${this.name} is eating ${food}.`);
  }
}

const myPet = new Animal("Fluffy", "cat", 2);
myPet.eat("fish");

In this example, we create a class Animal with a constructor that sets the name, type, and age properties. We also define a method eat that logs a message to the console. We then create an instance of the Animal class called myPet and call the eat method on it.

  1. Exercises and Solutions: Exercise 1: Create a subclass of Animal called Dog that has an additional property breed and a method bark that logs a message to the console.
javascript
class Dog extends Animal {
  constructor(name, breed, age) {
    super(name, "dog", age);
    this.breed = breed;
  }

  bark() {
    console.log(`${this.name} is barking! Woof!`);
  }
}

const myDog = new Dog("Max", "Golden Retriever", 4);
console.log(myDog);
myDog.eat("bones");
myDog.bark();

In this exercise, we create a subclass of Animal called Dog using the extends keyword. We add an additional property breed to the constructor and call the parent class constructor using super. We also define a new method bark that logs a message to the console. Finally, we create an instance of the Dog class called myDog and call the eat and bark methods on it.

Exercise 2: Use Object.assign to create a new object that combines properties from two existing objects.

javascript
const obj1 = { a: 1, b: 2 };
const obj2 = { b: 3, c: 4 };
const obj3 = Object.assign({}, obj1, obj2);
console.log(obj3);

In this exercise, we create two objects obj1 and obj2 with overlapping properties. We then use Object.assign to create a new object obj3 that combines the properties from both objects. The first argument to Object.assign is an empty object that is used as the target for the assignment. The subsequent arguments are the source objects to copy properties from. Finally, we log obj3 to the console to verify that the properties were successfully combined.

Reference Type
2 / 2

In JavaScript, there are two types of data types: primitive and reference. The primitive data types include numbers, strings, booleans, null, and undefined. Reference types, on the other hand, include objects and arrays.

Reference types are called such because they are stored and accessed by reference, rather than by value. This means that when you create an object or array in JavaScript, the variable that holds it doesn't actually contain the data. Instead, it contains a reference to the location in memory where the data is stored.

Here's an example:

javascript
let obj1 = { name: "John" };
let obj2 = obj1;

obj1.name = "Jane";

console.log(obj1.name); // "Jane"
console.log(obj2.name); // "Jane"

In this example, we create an object obj1 with a property name and set it equal to "John". Then, we create a new variable obj2 and set it equal to obj1. Since objects are reference types, obj2 now refers to the same object as obj1.

Next, we change the value of obj1.name to "Jane". Since obj1 and obj2 both refer to the same object, the change is reflected in both variables when we log their name property to the console.

Exercise 1:

javascript
let arr1 = [1, 2, 3];
let arr2 = arr1;

arr1.push(4);

console.log(arr1); // [1, 2, 3, 4]
console.log(arr2); // [1, 2, 3, 4]

Exercise 2:

javascript
let obj1 = { name: "John" };
let obj2 = { name: "John" };

console.log(obj1 === obj2); // false
console.log(obj1.name === obj2.name); // true

In Exercise 1, we create an array arr1 with three elements, then create a new variable arr2 and set it equal to arr1. We push a new element to arr1, and when we log both arrays to the console, we see that the change is reflected in both variables.

In Exercise 2, we create two separate objects obj1 and obj2, both with a property name set to "John". When we compare the two objects using the === operator, we see that they are not equal because they have different reference locations in memory. However, when we compare their name properties using obj1.name === obj2.name, we see that they are equal because their values are the same.

Context vs Scope
3 / 3

Context and scope are two important concepts in JavaScript that can often be confusing for beginners. Although they are related to each other, they are different concepts.

Scope refers to the visibility and accessibility of variables within a particular section of code. In JavaScript, scope is defined by the location of the variable declaration. There are two types of scope in JavaScript: global scope and local scope. Global scope means that the variable can be accessed from anywhere in the code, while local scope means that the variable can only be accessed within a specific block of code, such as a function.

Context, on the other hand, refers to the value of the 'this' keyword within a particular section of code. The 'this' keyword refers to the object that the function or code is being executed in. Context is determined by how a function is invoked, and it can change depending on the context in which the function is executed.

To summarize, scope is concerned with variable accessibility within a particular section of code, while context is concerned with the value of the 'this' keyword within that code.

Sure! Here's a summary for "Pass by Value vs Pass by Reference":

Description:

  • In JavaScript, variables can be passed to functions either by value or by reference.
  • When passed by value, the function receives a copy of the variable's value.
  • When passed by reference, the function receives a reference to the original variable.

Example:

scss
// pass by value
let num = 5;

function increment(num) {
  num++;
}

increment(num);
console.log(num); // 5

// pass by reference
let obj = { value: 5 };

function increment(obj) {
  obj.value++;
}

increment(obj);
console.log(obj.value); // 6

Exercises:

scss
function doubleArray(arr) {
  let newArr = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    newArr.push(arr[i] * 2);
  }
  return newArr;
}

let arr = [1, 2, 3];
let doubledArr = doubleArray(arr);
console.log(arr); // [1, 2, 3]
console.log(doubledArr); //

When a reference type is passed to a function, it is passed by reference. This means that the function receives a reference to the original value, and any changes made to the parameter within the function affect the original variable

Pass by Value and Pass by Reference are two ways of passing data to functions in JavaScript.

In pass by value, the value of a variable is passed to the function. This means that any changes made to the parameter inside the function do not affect the variable outside the function.

In pass by reference, a reference to an object or array is passed to the function. This means that any changes made to the parameter inside the function affect the original object or array outside the function.

Here is an example of pass by value:

javascript
let num = 5;

function increment(num) {
  num += 1;
  return num;
}

console.log(num); // Output: 5
console.log(increment(num)); // Output: 6
console.log(num); // Output: 5

Here is an example of pass by reference:

javascript
let arr = [1, 2, 3];

function addElement(arr, element) {
  arr.push(element);
  return arr;
}

console.log(arr); // Output: [1, 2, 3]
console.log(addElement(arr, 4)); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]
console.log(arr); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]

Exercise:

  2. Write a function addElement that takes an array and an element as arguments and adds the element to the end of the array. Test it with both pass by value and pass by reference.

Sure, here's the summary of Pass by Value vs Pass by Reference as per the instructions:

  1. Description:
  • In JavaScript, variables can be passed to functions either by value or by reference.
  • Pass by value means that a copy of the variable's value is passed to the function.
  • Pass by reference means that the variable's memory address is passed to the function.
  1. Example:
javascript
let num = 10;
let str = "hello";
let arr = [1, 2, 3];

function modify(num, str, arr) {
  num = 20;         // this modifies the copied value
  str += " world";  // this creates a new string, doesn't modify the original
  arr.push(4);      // this modifies the original array
}

modify(num, str, arr);

console.log(num);  // 10
console.log(str);  // "hello"
console.log(arr);  // [1, 2, 3, 4]
  • This example shows the difference between pass by value and pass by reference.
  • The function modifies the copied value of num, creates a new string from str, and modifies the original arr.
  1. Exercises and solutions:

Exercise 1:

javascript

function modify(obj) {
  obj.name = "Jane";
}

modify(obj);

console.log(obj.name);  // "Jane"
  • This exercise demonstrates pass by reference.
  • The function modifies the object's property.

Exercise 2:

javascript
let num = 10;

function modify(num) {
  num *= 2;
  return num;
}

let newNum = modify(num);

console.log(num);     // 10
console.log(newNum);  // 20
  • This exercise demonstrates pass by value.
  • The function returns a new value, without modifying the original.

Sure, here's a summary on cloning objects:

  1. Description: Cloning an object in JavaScript creates a copy of the original object. However, the copy is independent of the original, and any changes made to the copy won't affect the original object.

  2. Example: Let's say we have an object person with two properties name and age. We want to clone this object into a new object personClone. We can do this using the spread operator like so:

javascript
const person = { name: "John", age: 25 };
const personClone = { ...person };

Now personClone is an independent copy of person. We can modify personClone without affecting person, like so:

javascript
personClone.name = "Jane";
personClone.age = 30;

person and personClone now have different values for name and age.

  1. Exercises: a) Write a function cloneObject that takes an object as an argument and returns a clone of that object. The function should work for objects with any number of properties.

b) Write a function deepCloneObject that takes an object as an argument and returns a deep clone of that object. A deep clone means that any nested objects and arrays are also cloned. The function should work for objects with any number of nested objects or arrays.

Solutions:

a)

javascript
function cloneObject(obj) {
  return { ...obj };
}

// Example usage:
const person = { name: "John", age: 25 };
const personClone = cloneObject(person);

b)

javascript
function deepCloneObject(obj) {
  if (typeof obj !== "object" || obj === null) {
    // Base case for non-objects and null
    return obj;
  }

  let clone;
  if (Array.isArray(obj)) {
    // If obj is an array, create an empty array to clone into
    clone = [];
  } else {
    // Otherwise, create an empty object to clone into
    clone = {};
  }

  for (let key in obj) {
    // Recursively clone each property
    clone[key] = deepCloneObject(obj[key]);
  }

  return clone;
}

// Example usage:
const person = { 
  name: "John", 
  age: 25, 
  address: { 
    street: "123 Main St", 
    city: "New York" 
  } 
};
const personClone = deepCloneObject(person);
personClone.address.street = "456 Park Ave";
console.log(person.address.street); // Output: 123 Main St

Sure, here is the summary for Clone Objects:

  1. Description:
  • Cloning an object means creating a new object with the same properties and values as the original one.
  • The cloned object is a copy of the original one, but they are two different objects stored in different memory locations.
  • Cloning is important because it allows you to modify the properties of the cloned object without affecting the original object.
  1. Example:
javascript
// creating an object
let originalObj = { name: "John", age: 30 };

// cloning the object using spread operator
let clonedObj = { ...originalObj };

// modifying the cloned object without affecting the original object
clonedObj.name = "Jane";

// printing the values of both objects
console.log(originalObj); // { name: "John", age: 30 }
console.log(clonedObj); // { name: "Jane", age: 30 }
  • In the example, we first create an object called originalObj with two properties name and age.
  • Then, we clone the object using the spread operator ... and store it in a new variable called clonedObj.
  • After that, we modify the name property of the clonedObj without affecting the originalObj.
  • Finally, we print the values of both objects and see that only the clonedObj has the updated name property.
  1. Exercises and Solutions: Exercise 1:
  • Create an object called person with properties name, age, and gender.

Sure, here's a summary for cloning objects in JavaScript:

  1. Description: When we clone an object in JavaScript, we create a new object with the same properties and values as the original object. There are several ways to clone objects in JavaScript, each with its own advantages and disadvantages.

  2. Example:

javascript
// Creating an object
const originalObj = {a: 1, b: 2};

// Shallow clone using object spread
const shallowClone = {...originalObj};
shallowClone.a = 3;

console.log(originalObj); // {a: 1, b: 2}
console.log(shallowClone); // {a: 3, b: 2}

// Deep clone using JSON
const deepClone = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(originalObj));
deepClone.a = 4;

console.log(originalObj); // {a: 1, b: 2}
console.log(deepClone); // {a: 4, b: 2}
  1. Exercises and Solutions:

console.log(shallowCloneObj); // {a: 1, b: 2}
console.log(originalObj === shallowCloneObj); // false

Sure, here's another summary on cloning objects:

  1. Short Description: Cloning objects in JavaScript refers to creating a copy of an object, rather than just creating a reference to it. This means that changes made to the cloned object do not affect the original object.

  2. Example:

css
// create an object
const originalObj = {
  name: 'John',
  age: 30,
  address: {
    city: 'New York',
    state: 'NY'
  }
};

// cloning object using spread operator
const clonedObj = { ...originalObj };

// modifying the cloned object
clonedObj.name = 'Jane';
clonedObj.address.city = 'Chicago';

console.log(originalObj); // { name: 'John', age: 30, address: { city: 'New York', state: 'NY' } }
console.log(clonedObj); // { name: 'Jane', age: 30, address: { city: 'Chicago', state: 'NY' } }

In this example, we create an original object with nested properties. We then clone the object using the spread operator and modify the cloned object. As we can see in the console logs, the original object remains unchanged, while the cloned object reflects the changes made to it.

  1. Exercises: a) Write a function that takes an object as an argument and returns a cloned object. Use the spread operator to clone the object.
javascript
function cloneObject(obj) {
  return {...obj};
}

// example usage
const originalObj = {a: 1, b: 2, c: 3};
const clonedObj = cloneObject(originalObj);

console.log(originalObj); // {a: 1, b: 2, c: 3}
console.log(clonedObj); // {a: 1, b: 2, c: 3}
console.log(originalObj === clonedObj); // false

b) Write a function that takes an object as an argument and returns a deep clone of the object. Use recursion to clone nested properties.

css
function deepCloneObject(obj) {
  let clone = {};
  for (let key in obj) {
    if (typeof obj[key] === 'object' && obj[key] !== null) {
      clone[key] = deepCloneObject(obj[key]);
    } else {
      clone[key] = obj[key];
    }
  }
  return clone;
}

// example usage
const originalObj = {
  a: 1,
  b: {
    c: 2,
    d: [3, 4, {e: 5}]
  }
};

const clonedObj = deepCloneObject(originalObj);

console.log(originalObj); // { a: 1, b: { c: 2, d: [ 3, 4, { e: 5 } ] } }
console.log(clonedObj); // { a: 1, b: { c: 2, d: [ 3, 4, { e: 5 } ] } }
console.log(originalObj === clonedObj); // false
console.log(originalObj.b.d[2] === clonedObj.b.d[2]); // false

In this example, we create an original object with nested properties of various types. We then use recursion to create a deep clone of the object, where all nested properties are also cloned. We can see in the console logs that the original and cloned objects are equal, but not the same object in memory.

Sure, here's a summary for Shallow Cloning:

  1. Description: Shallow cloning is a technique used to create a new object that has the same properties as the original object, but with a different reference in memory. Shallow cloning creates a new object with a new reference, but it does not create a deep copy of the original object's properties. clonedObj.address.city = "Los Angeles";

Sure, here's a summary for Shallow Cloning:

  1. Description: Shallow Cloning is the process of creating a new object with the same properties as the original object, but with the property values being references to the same objects in memory.

  2. Example:

javascript
// Original object
const obj1 = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  address: {
    city: "New York",
    country: "USA"
  }
};

const obj2 = Object.assign({}, obj1);

// Update the value of the nested object property
obj2.address.city = "Los Angeles";

console.log(obj1.address.city); // Output: Los Angeles

In the example above, we have an object obj1 with a nested object property address. We create a shallow clone of obj1 using Object.assign() and assign it to obj2. We update the value of the city property of the nested object in obj2, which also updates the value in the original object obj1.

Sure, here's a summary of Deep Cloning:

  1. Short Description: Deep cloning is the process of creating a new object with the same properties and values as an existing object, including nested objects and arrays. It creates a complete copy of the original object, whereas shallow cloning only creates a copy of the top-level properties.

  2. Example:

javascript
let obj = {
  name: 'John',
  age: 30,
  address: {
    street: '123 Main St',
    city: 'New York',
    state: 'NY'
  }
};

let objCopy = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(obj));

console.log(objCopy);

// Output: { name: 'John', age: 30, address: { street: '123 Main St', city: 'New York', state: 'NY' } }

In this example, we have an object obj with a nested object address. To create a deep clone of obj, we use JSON.stringify() to convert the object to a JSON string, and then JSON.parse() to parse the JSON string and create a new object with the same properties and values. This creates a complete copy of the original object, including the nested object address.

Sure! Here's a summary on deep cloning in JavaScript:

  1. Short Description: Deep cloning is a technique used to create a new object with the same properties as the original, but with new memory allocated to store those properties. It ensures that the cloned object is completely independent from the original object.

  2. Example:

javascript
const originalObj = { a: 1, b: { c: 2 } };
const clonedObj = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(originalObj));

// The cloned object is a new object
console.log(clonedObj === originalObj); // false

// The cloned object has the same properties as the original object
console.log(clonedObj.a); // 1
console.log(clonedObj.b.c); // 2

// The cloned object is completely independent from the original object
originalObj.a = 3;
originalObj.b.c = 4;
console.log(originalObj.a); // 3
console.log(originalObj.b.c); // 4
console.log(clonedObj.a); // 1
console.log(clonedObj.b.c); // 2

In this example, we create an original object with two properties, one of which is an object. We then use the JSON.stringify() and JSON.parse() methods to deep clone the object. The cloned object is a new object that has the same properties as the original object. Modifying the original object does not affect the cloned object, and vice versa.

  1. Exercises: Exercise 1: Write a function that takes an object as an argument and returns a deep copy of that object.
javascript
function deepClone(obj) {
  return JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(obj));
}

const originalObj = { a: 1, b: { c: 2 } };
const clonedObj = deepClone(originalObj);

// The cloned object is a new object
console.log(clonedObj === originalObj); // false

// The cloned object has the same properties as the original object
console.log(clonedObj.a); // 1
console.log(clonedObj.b.c); // 2

// The cloned object is completely independent from the original object
originalObj.a = 3;
originalObj.b.c = 4;
console.log(originalObj.a); // 3
console.log(originalObj.b.c); // 4
console.log(clonedObj.a); // 1
console.log(clonedObj.b.c); // 2

Exercise 2: Write a function that takes an array of objects as an argument and returns a deep copy of that array.

javascript
function deepCloneArray(arr) {
  return JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(arr));
}

const originalArr = [{ a: 1 }, { b: 2 }];
const clonedArr = deepCloneArray(originalArr);

// The cloned array is a new array
console.log(clonedArr === originalArr); // false

// The cloned array has the same elements as the original array
console.log(clonedArr[0].a); // 1
console.log(clonedArr[1].b); // 2

// The cloned array is completely independent from the original array
originalArr[0].a = 3;
originalArr[1].b = 4;
console.log(originalArr[0].a); // 3
console.log(originalArr[1].b); // 4
console.log(clonedArr[0].a); // 1
console.log(clonedArr[1].b); // 2

In this exercise, we use the deepClone() function from the previous exercise to create a deep clone of an array of objects. The cloned array is a new array that has the same elements as the original array.

Sure, here is the summary:

  1. Short Description: ES2017 introduced some new features and improvements to JavaScript, including string padding, trailing commas in function parameter lists, and function calls.

  • String Padding: It allows adding a specific character at the beginning or end of a string to achieve a certain length.

  • Trailing Commas in Functions: It allows placing a comma after the last parameter in a function's parameter list.

  • Trailing Commas in Function Calls: It allows placing a comma after the last argument in a function call.

  1. Example:

String Padding:

javascript
const name = 'John';
console.log(name.padStart(7, 'X')); // "XXXJohn"
console.log(name.padEnd(7, 'X')); // "JohnXXX"

// The padStart() method adds the specified characters to the beginning of a string until it reaches the desired length. The padEnd() method does the same but adds the characters to the end of the string.

Trailing Commas:

javascript
function sum(a, b, c,) {
  return a + b + c;
}

sum(1, 2, 3,);

// In the sum function, there is a trailing comma after the last parameter. The function call also has a trailing comma after the last argument.

  1. Short Description: Maps are a collection of key-value pairs where both the key and the value can be of any type. Maps can be accessed and manipulated using built-in methods such as Object.keys(), Object.values(), and Object.entries().

  2. Example:

javascript
const myMap = new Map();
myMap.set('name', 'John');
myMap.set('age', 25);

console.log(Object.keys(myMap)); // ['name', 'age']
console.log(Object.values(myMap)); // ['John', 25]
console.log(Object.entries(myMap)); // [['name', 'John'], ['age', 25]]

// The above code creates a new Map and adds two key-value pairs to it. Then, it uses the built-in methods Object.keys(), Object.values(), and Object.entries() to get an array of keys, values, and entries respectively.

c
function sortKeys(map) {
  const keysArray = Array.from(map.keys());
  return keysArray.sort();
}

const myMap = new Map();
myMap.set('b', 1);
myMap.set('a', 2);
myMap.set('c', 3);

console.log(sortKeys(myMap)); // ['a', 'b', 'c']

// The above function takes in a Map and uses the Array.from() method to convert the Map keys into an array. Then, it sorts the array and returns it.

b) Write a function that takes in an array of key-value pairs and returns a Map.

javascript
function arrayToMap(arr) {
  const map = new Map();
  arr.forEach(([key, value]) => {
    map.set(key, value);
  });
  return map;
}

const myArray = [['name', 'John'], ['age', 25]];

console.log(arrayToMap(myArray)); // Map { 'name' => 'John', 'age' => 25 }

// The above function takes in an array of key-value pairs and uses the forEach() method to iterate over the array and add each pair to a new Map. Finally, it returns the Map.

Continue in the same style with same rule and give me another summary for: Maps - Object.keys, Object.values, Object.entries.
1 / 1

Sure, here is a summary for Maps and their Object methods:

  1. Short Description: Maps are a collection of key-value pairs where keys can be any type of values, not just strings like in objects. Object.keys, Object.values, and Object.entries are three built-in methods that work with Maps to return arrays of their keys, values, and entries.

  2. Example:

javascript
// Creating a new Map
const myMap = new Map();

// Setting values for the Map
myMap.set("name", "John");
myMap.set("age", 30);
myMap.set(true, "isMarried");

// Using Object.keys to get an array of keys
const keys = Object.keys(Object.fromEntries(myMap));
console.log(keys); // ["name", "age", "true"]

// Using Object.values to get an array of values
const values = Object.values(Object.fromEntries(myMap));
console.log(values); // ["John", 30, "isMarried"]

// Using Object.entries to get an array of key-value pairs
const entries = Object.entries(Object.fromEntries(myMap));
console.log(entries); // [["name", "John"], ["age", 30], [true, "isMarried"]]

In this example, we first create a new Map called myMap and set some values to it. Then, we use Object.keys, Object.values, and Object.entries with the fromEntries method to get an array of keys, values, and entries of the Map.

  1. Exercises and Solutions: a. Write a function that takes a Map and returns an array of values with the keys that contain a specific string.
javascript
function findValuesByKeySubstring(map, substring) {
  const values = [];
  for (const [key, value] of map.entries()) {
    if (key.includes(substring)) {
      values.push(value);
    }
  }
  return values;
}

// Example usage
const myMap = new Map();
myMap.set("name", "John");
myMap.set("age", 30);
myMap.set(true, "isMarried");

const result = findValuesByKeySubstring(myMap, "a");
console.log(result); // ["John", 30]

In this function, we first initialize an empty array called values. Then, we loop through the Map using the entries method to check if each key includes the substring. If it does, we push the corresponding value to the values array. Finally, we return the values array.

b. Write a function that takes two Maps and merges them into one Map, with the second Map overriding values of the first Map if they have the same keys.

javascript
function mergeMaps(map1, map2) {
  const mergedMap = new Map([...map1, ...map2]);
  return mergedMap;
}

// Example usage
const map1 = new Map([["a", 1], ["b", 2], ["c", 3]]);
const map2 = new Map([["b", 4], ["c", 5], ["d", 6]]);

const merged = mergeMaps(map1, map2);
console.log(merged); // Map(4) { 'a' => 1, 'b' => 4, 'c' => 5, 'd' => 6 }

In this function, we use the spread operator to combine the two Maps into an array of key-value pairs, then pass it to the Map constructor to create a new Map. Since the second Map's values will override the first Map's values if they have the same keys, the final Map will contain the merged values.

  • flat method flattens a multidimensional array into a one-dimensional array.

Continue in the same style with same rules and give me another summary for: Try Catch Block
2 / 2
  • Try-Catch Block

A try-catch block is a programming construct used in JavaScript to handle errors or exceptions that can occur during the execution of a program. It consists of two parts, the try block and the catch block.

  • Example

The code below demonstrates the use of a try-catch block:

javascript
try {
  // code that might throw an error or exception
  let result = 5 / 0;
} catch (error) {
  // code that handles the error or exception
  console.log('Error:', error.message);
}

In this example, the try block contains code that performs a division by zero operation which will throw an error. The catch block contains code that will handle the error by logging the error message to the console.

  • Exercises
  1. Write a function that takes two parameters and returns their sum. Use a try-catch block to handle the scenario where the parameters are not numbers and return a message indicating that the parameters must be numbers.
javascript
function sum(a, b) {
  try {
    if (typeof a !== 'number' || typeof b !== 'number') {
      throw new Error('Both parameters must be numbers');
    }
    return a + b;
  } catch (error) {
    console.log(error.message);
  }
}

console.log(sum(1, 2)); // Output: 3
console.log(sum(1, '2')); // Output: 'Both parameters must be numbers'
  1. Write a function that takes an array of numbers and returns the sum of the array. Use a try-catch block to handle the scenario where one of the array elements is not a number and return a message indicating that all array elements must be numbers.
javascript
function sumArray(array) {
  try {
    array.forEach((element) => {
      if (typeof element !== 'number') {
        throw new Error('All array elements must be numbers');
      }
    });
    return array.reduce((accumulator, currentValue) => accumulator + currentValue);
  } catch (error) {
    console.log(error.message);
  }
}

console.log(sumArray([1, 2, 3])); // Output: 6
console.log(sumArray([1, 2, '3'])); // Output: 'All array elements must be numbers'

In the first exercise, the function sum takes two parameters a and b and returns their sum. A try-catch block is used to handle the scenario where the parameters are not numbers and a message is logged to the console.

In the second exercise, the function sumArray takes an array of numbers and returns their sum. A try-catch block is used to handle the scenario where one of the array elements is not a number and a message is logged to the console.

  • Advanced Loops – Iterating, Enumerating, for of, for in

    • Iterating over an array means going through each element of an array in order, and performing some operation on each element.
    • The for loop is the most basic method for iterating over an array in JavaScript.
    • The for...of loop is a new feature added in ES6 which provides a more concise way to iterate over an array. It can be used to loop over any iterable object, not just arrays.
    • The for...in loop is used to loop over the keys of an object. It is not recommended to use it for iterating over arrays because it may not iterate in the expected order, and it may include non-index properties of the array.
    • The forEach() method is another way to iterate over an array in JavaScript. It takes a callback function as its argument and calls that function once for each element in the array.

    Example:

    javascript
    const fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"];

// for loop
for (let i = 0; i < fruits.length; i++) {
  console.log(fruits[i]);
}

// for...of loop
for (const fruit of fruits) {
  console.log(fruit);
}

// forEach() method
fruits.forEach(function(fruit) {
  console.log(fruit);
});

const person = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  city: "New York"
};

// for...in loop
for (const key in person) {
  console.log(`${key}: ${person[key]}`);
}

    // Output:

    vbnet
    apple
banana
cherry
apple
banana
cherry
apple
banana
cherry
name: John
age: 30
city: New York

    Exercise 1: Write a function sumArray that takes an array of numbers as input and returns the sum of all the numbers in the array. Use a for...of loop to iterate over the array.

    javascript
    function sumArray(arr) {
  let sum = 0;
  for (const num of arr) {
    sum += num;
  }
  return sum;
}

console.log(sumArray([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])); // Output: 15

    Exercise 2: Write a function countWords that takes a string as input and returns an object with the count of each word in the string. Use a for...of loop to iterate over the words in the string.

    javascript
    function countWords(str) {
  const words = str.split(" ");
  const wordCount = {};
  for (const word of words) {
    if (wordCount[word]) {
      wordCount[word]++;
    } else {
      wordCount[word] = 1;
    }
  }
  return wordCount;
}

console.log(countWords("the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog")); 
// Output: {the: 2, quick: 1, brown: 1, fox: 1, jumps: 1, over: 1, lazy: 1, dog: 1}

Continue in the same style with the same rules and give me another summary for: BigInt
5 / 5

  • Description: BigInt is a built-in data type in JavaScript that was introduced in ES2020. It is a way to represent integers that are larger than the maximum value allowed for the Number data type. BigInt values are represented by appending the n character to the end of the integer literal.

  • Example:

javascript
const maxNumber = Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER; // 9007199254740991
console.log(maxNumber + 1); // 9007199254740992
console.log(maxNumber + 2); // 9007199254740992
console.log(maxNumber + 3); // 9007199254740994
console.log(maxNumber + 4); // 9007199254740996
console.log(maxNumber + 5); // 9007199254740996
const bigIntNumber = 9007199254740991n;
console.log(bigIntNumber + 1n); // 9007199254740992n
console.log(bigIntNumber + 2n); // 9007199254740993n
console.log(bigIntNumber + 3n); // 9007199254740994n
console.log(bigIntNumber + 4n); // 9007199254740995n
console.log(bigIntNumber + 5n); // 9007199254740996n

In this example, we can see that the Number data type has a maximum safe integer value of 9007199254740991, so adding 1 to it gives us the same value due to overflow. However, when we use the BigInt data type, we can correctly perform arithmetic operations on integers that are larger than 9007199254740991.

  • 2 Exercises and their solutions:

Exercise 1: Write a function that calculates the factorial of a given number using BigInt.

javascript
function factorial(n) {
  let result = 1n;
  for (let i = 2n; i <= n; i++) {
    result *= i;
  }
  return result;
}

console.log(factorial(10)); // 3628800n
console.log(factorial(20)); // 2432902008176640000n
console.log(factorial(50)); // 30414093201713378043612608166064768844377641568960512000000000000n

Exercise 2: Write a function that returns true if a given number is a Fibonacci number, otherwise false.

less
function isFibonacciNumber(n) {
  let a = 0n, b = 1n;
  while (b < n) {
    const temp = b;
    b += a;
    a = temp;
  }
  return b === n;
}

console.log(isFibonacciNumber(13n)); // true
console.log(isFibonacciNumber(21n)); // true
console.log(isFibonacciNumber(34n)); // true
console.log(isFibonacciNumber(35n)); // false
console.log(isFibonacciNumber(55n)); // true

Continue in the same style with the same rules and give me another summary for: Optional Chaining Operator ?.
1 / 1
  • Optional Chaining Operator (?.) is a feature introduced in ES2020 that allows developers to safely access deeply nested properties of an object without throwing errors if a property is nullish (null or undefined).
  • The operator works by checking if the property exists at each level of the object hierarchy before attempting to access it. If any of the properties in the chain is nullish, the entire chain will return undefined instead of throwing an error.
  • Here's an example of how the optional chaining operator can be used in JavaScript:
javascript
const obj = {
  a: {
    b: {
      c: 42
    }
  }
};

// Without Optional Chaining
if (obj && obj.a && obj.a.b && obj.a.b.c) {
  console.log(obj.a.b.c); // Output: 42
} else {
  console.log('Property does not exist.');
}

// With Optional Chaining
console.log(obj?.a?.b?.c); // Output: 42
console.log(obj?.x?.y?.z); // Output: undefined
  • In the above example, the first log statement uses traditional property access and checks each level of the object hierarchy manually. The second log statement uses the optional chaining operator to access the same property, resulting in more concise and readable code.
  • It's important to note that the optional chaining operator should not be overused, as it can lead to unexpected behavior if not used properly. It's best used for accessing properties of nested objects when there's a possibility of encountering nullish values along the way.

Here are two exercises that demonstrate the use of the optional chaining operator:

Exercise 1:

javascript
const obj = {
  a: {
    b: {
      c: {
        d: 42
      }
    }
  }
};

// Use optional chaining to get the value of property d
console.log(obj?.a?.b?.c?.d); // Output: 42

Exercise 2:

javascript
const arr = [null, undefined, { foo: 'bar' }];

// Use optional chaining to get the value of property foo
console.log(arr[2]?.foo); // Output: 'bar'
console.log(arr[0]?.foo); // Output: undefined

In the first exercise, we use the optional chaining operator to access the deeply nested property d of the obj object. In the second exercise, we use it to safely access the foo property of an object at a particular index of an array, even when the array contains nullish values.

Sure, here's another summary for the Optional Chaining Operator:

  1. Short Description: The Optional Chaining Operator ?. is a feature introduced in ES2020 that allows you to safely access properties and methods of an object, even if the object or any of its nested properties are null or undefined.

  2. Example:

javascript
const person = {
  name: 'John',
  address: {
    city: 'New York',
    zip: 10001
  }
};

// Accessing a nested property without optional chaining:
console.log(person.address.street); // TypeError: Cannot read property 'street' of undefined

// Accessing a nested property with optional chaining:
console.log(person.address?.street); // undefined

// Calling a method without optional chaining:
console.log(person.address.calculateDistance()); // TypeError: Cannot read property 'calculateDistance' of undefined

// Calling a method with optional chaining:
console.log(person.address?.calculateDistance?.()); // undefined

In the above example, the Optional Chaining Operator is used to safely access the street property of the person object's address property, which is not defined. Similarly, it is used to safely call the calculateDistance method of the person object's address property, which is also not defined.

  1. Exercises:

Exercise 2: Write a function that takes an object as a parameter and returns the value of the id property of the user property of the object, if it exists. If the user property or the id property of the user property is not defined, the function should return null.

javascript
function getUserId(obj) {
  if (obj.user && obj.user.id) {
    return obj.user.id;
  } else {
    return null;
  }

function getUserId(obj) {
  return obj.user?.id ?? null;

const user1 = {
  name: 'John',
  age: 30,
  user: {
    id: 123,
    email: 'john@example.com'
  }
};

const user2 = {
  name: 'Alice',
  age: 25,
  user: null
};

console.log(getUserId(user1)); // 123
console.log(getUserId(user2)); // null

In the above solution, the Optional Chaining Operator is used to safely access the id property of the user property of the object, even if the user property is not defined. The nullish coalescing operator (??) is used to return null if the id property is not defined.

Continue in the same style with the same rules and give me another summary for: 40. Nullish Coalescing Operator ??
2 / 2
  • Nullish Coalescing Operator (??) is a logical operator that returns the right-hand side operand when the left-hand side operand is null or undefined, otherwise returns the left-hand side operand.
  • It's used to provide a default value when the value is nullish, which means it's null or undefined.

Example:

javascript
const value1 = null;
const value2 = undefined;
const value3 = '';
const value4 = 0;

console.log(value1 ?? 'Default Value'); // Output: Default Value
console.log(value2 ?? 'Default Value'); // Output: Default Value
console.log(value3 ?? 'Default Value'); // Output: ""
console.log(value4 ?? 'Default Value'); // Output: 0

// The ?? operator returns the default value 'Default Value' in the first two examples where value1 and value2 are null or undefined. It returns the empty string in the third example because the value3 is an empty string which is not nullish. And it returns 0 in the last example because 0 is not nullish.

Exercise 1:

javascript
function getDisplayName(user) {
  return user?.name ?? 'Guest';
}

const user1 = { name: 'John' };
const user2 = { email: 'john@example.com' };
const user3 = null;

console.log(getDisplayName(user1)); // Output: John
console.log(getDisplayName(user2)); // Output: Guest
console.log(getDisplayName(user3)); // Output: Guest

// The getDisplayName function accepts a user object as an argument and returns the name property of the user object if it exists, otherwise returns the default value 'Guest'. The optional chaining operator (?.) is used to access the name property of the user object safely, without throwing an error if the user object is null or undefined.

Exercise 2:

    city: 'New York',

  }
};

console.log(phoneNumber); // Output: Unknown

// The first example uses the optional chaining operator (?.) to safely access the country property of the address object of the user object. The operator returns the value of the country property if it exists, otherwise returns the default value 'Unknown'. The output is 'USA' because the country property exists in the user object's address object.

// The second example uses the optional chaining operator to safely access the phoneNumber property of the user object. The operator returns undefined because the phoneNumber property does not exist in the user object. The nullish coalescing operator (??) returns the default value 'Unknown'.

  • ES2022 - .at The .at() method is a new feature introduced in ES2022 that allows you to retrieve the element of an array at a specific index, similar to the existing [] bracket notation. However, unlike the bracket notation, the .at() method supports negative indices and out-of-bounds indices.

  • Example:

arduino
const arr = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'];

console.log(arr.at(2)); // 'c'
console.log(arr.at(-1)); // 'd'
console.log(arr.at(10)); // undefined

  • In this example, we have an array arr with four elements. We use the .at() method to retrieve the element at index 2, which is 'c'. We also use it to retrieve the last element of the array by passing in a negative index of -1, which returns 'd'. Finally, we pass in an index of 10, which is out of bounds for the array and therefore returns undefined.

Continue in the same style with the same rules and give me another summary for: Async/Await
3 / 3

Async/Await is a feature in JavaScript that allows for asynchronous code to be written in a synchronous style, making it easier to read and understand. The "async" keyword is used to mark a function as asynchronous, and the "await" keyword is used to pause the execution of a function until a promise is resolved. This way, the code can wait for an asynchronous task to complete before moving on to the next line of code, making it more readable and easier to follow. Async/await is a powerful tool for working with APIs, databases, and other time-consuming operations, and is now widely used in modern JavaScript development.
